coverDetails.about: Five Star offers small business loans which are fully secured by the properties of borrowers. The company is led by a capable and experienced management team that follows best practices in underwriting, collections and overall operations which have led to resilient growth, improvement in asset quality and profitability despite stress related to demonetization, GST and recently the COVID 19 pandemic.

whyYouShouldInvest.value: Robust AUM growth, projected CAGR of 51% from FY18-FY23 (Peers: ~10%-25% CAGR in the same period)
A right business model, ALM & capital structure - Capital Adequacy Ratio of 59% (min. 15% by regulation) and D/E ratio - 1.5x
Maintained industry leading asset quality (c.1% GNPA) making it an attractive player in a resilient market with high unmet need
RoA and RoE of c.9% and c.17% respectively. Stands out relative to peers in all KPIs (return ratios, asset quality, AUM growth etc.)

ourPromise.body: Our proprietary framework analyzes and evaluates all opportunities to pick the best that fits your portfolio
We thrive to democratize exclusive opportunities by lowering minimum ticket size, ensuring allotment and simplifying investment process
We pick opportunities backed by marquee investors, as shown below

investmentDetails.lockInPeriod: Mandatory holding period of 6 months post listing
taxImplication: Unlisted shares (< 2 years): Based on income tax slabs

faq.question: What is the meaning of Pre-IPO?
faq.answer: Pre-IPO means buying/selling shares in a company before its IPO i.e. before it gets listed on the Stock Exchanges.

faq.question: Who sells shares in a pre-IPO?
faq.answer: Existing shareholders of the Company sell shares in the pre-IPO.

faq.question: Is the Company involved in selling shares in a pre-IPO?
faq.answer: No.This is a secondary off market transaction and the Company is NOT involved in any way in the transaction.

faq.question: Are the shares being sold in the demat form?
faq.answer: Yes.The shares being sold are in the demat form.

faq.question: If a company is not listed,how come the shares are in the demat form?
faq.answer: Any company which has more than 100 shareholders can pass a Board resolution and get its shares dematerialised with NSDL/CDSL.

faq.question: What is the kind of time horizon involved in investing in Pre-IPOs?
faq.answer: Most pre-IPOs take anywhere from 6 months to 3 years to get listed as it involves taking shareholder approval, getting internal processes in order, hiring merchant bankers, filing DRHP, getting SEBI approvals etc.

faq.question: What is the minimum amount one can invest in a Pre-IPO?
faq.answer: Depending on the opportunity,the minimum amount can be vary but we try to minimize it as much as we can.

faq.question: Do the pre-IPO shares have any lock-in?
faq.answer: Yes. As per SEBI rules,all pre-IPO shares have a lock-in for six months from the date of listing.

faq.question: What is the kind of returns one can expect in investing in pre-IPO?
faq.answer: Depends on the Company and its management’s execution capabilities. In Equities, nobody can guarantee any kind of returns.

faq.question: What are the kinds of risks involved in investing in pre-IPO?
faq.answer:
Essentially, there are three following risks which matter the most:
A. Management Risk - The Company Management may execute poorly and the Company’s results falter.
B. Timeline Risk - The Company takes longer than expected to get listed.
C. Liquidity Risk - Unlisted shares are inherently illiquid and you may not be able to sell your shares in a hurry.

faq.question: What are the tax implications of investing in pre-IPO?
faq.answer: Capital gains on sale of unlisted shares will be classified as long term, if held for more than 24 months. STCG on sale of unlisted equity shares is taxable at applicable marginal tax rate. LTCG on sale of unlisted equity shares is taxable at 20% with indexation.

faq.question: How do you select opportunities to invest in?
faq.answer: We have our in-house team of experts who perform detailed evaluation, analysis and diligence on the opportunities. Our team of experts have created models, frameworks, evaluation structures to research on such opportunities.

coverDetails.about: Piramal Capital & Housing Finance Limited (PCHFL), is a wholly-owned subsidiary of Piramal Enterprises Limited (PEL). The company provides home loans & mortgage loans in tier I & tier II regions. Under retail platform the company has also started offering secured business loans and loans against property. PCHFL benefits from group synergies in the form of shared ‘Piramal’ brand name, capital, managerial and operational support from the parent.

whyYouShouldInvest.value: Offers a high yield (10.25%) and lucrative tax efficient returns despite a high credit rating
Capital Adequacy Ratio of 32% (min. 15% by regulation) in FY21 with a leverage ratio of 2.7x
The group has repeatedly demonstrated ability to raise capital - ~Rs.7,000 Cr. of fresh equity in FY18 and ~Rs.5,400 Cr. in FY20
Hangover of DHFL acquisition is over, leading to reduction in cost of borrowing, diversification into retail, increase D/E ratio and ROE improvement

ourPromise.body: We thrive to democratize exclusive opportunities by lowering minimum ticket size, ensuring allotment and simplifying investment process
We offer competitive pricing for all transactions on our platform, all details are available with full transparency

taxImplication: Listed NCDs (sold < 1 year): based on income tax slabs
Listed NCDs (sold > 1 year or before maturity): ~10% without indexation
Interest income: Similar as fixed income securities under income from other sources.

faq.question: What is a bond?
faq.answer: A bond is a fixed-income financial instrument that represents a loan made by an investor to a borrower (typically corporate or governmental). Owners of bonds are usually known as debtholders, or creditors, of the issuer.

faq.question: Why are bonds issued / what is the use?
faq.answer: Bonds are used by companies, municipalities, states, and sovereign governments to finance projects and operations.

faq.question: What is the primary details one should look for in a bond?
faq.answer: Bond details typically include the end date when the principal of the loan is due to be paid to the bond owner and usually include the terms for variable or fixed interest payments made by the borrower (depdning on nature of instrument).

faq.question: What is the minimum investment amount to buy bonds?
faq.answer: Depending on the opportunity, the minimum amount can be vary but we try to minimize it as much as we can.

faq.question: What is the face value, coupon, yield, price, listing status, etc. of the bond?
faq.answer: The above instrument details are all shared along with the opportunity on the respective deal screen. Each offering on our platform is curated and thus all the relevant details will be shared directly with it.

faq.question: What do you mean by nature of instrument?
faq.answer: Nature of the instrument typically comprises of characterstics such as coupon type (fixed or variable), rated, secured, seniority, listed etc.

faq.question: How do you shortlist the instruments?
faq.answer: We have our in-house team of experts who perform detailed evaluation, analysis and diligence on the opportunities. Our team of experts have created models, frameworks, evaluation structures to research on such opportunities.

faq.question: What are the kinds of risks involved in investing in bonds?
faq.answer:
Essentially,there are four following risks which matter the most:
A. Interest rate risk - Since the price of a bond changes with the changes in the market interest rates, the risks that an investor gets to face is that the price of a bond will drop in case the market interest rates rise.
B. Credit risk - Failure in timely payment of interest by principal issuer will let the investor face credit risk, investors who invest in the bonds of companies with poor credit ratings are generally subjected to higher risk.
C. Liquidity risk - The company facing difficulty in selling an asset is termed as Liquidity Risk. In the case of bonds too selling a bond below its indicated value may expose the investor to liquidity risk. When an investor wants to sell a bond prior to the maturity date, he is concerned with whether or not the bid price from broker or dealers is near enough to the indicated value of the issue.
D. Inflation risk - This risk rises from the decline in the value of a security’s cash flows due to inflation may result in Inflation risk.

faq.question: Why is the yield different from the coupon rate?
faq.answer:
The yield to maturity (YTM) is the rate of return (in %) for a bond considering that an investor would hold the asset until maturity. A bond's yield to maturity rises or falls depending on its market value and how many payments remain to be made.
The coupon rate is the annual amount of interest that the owner of the bond will receive.

faq.question: What is the difference in primary and secondary issuance?
faq.answer: The primary issuance is where securities are created for the first time and then sold/distributed, while the secondary issuance is where those securities are traded by investors.
